comments.commentBody: Excellent, insightful post. As a book-lover in the traditional sense, talk of a drastic paradigm shift away from paper and print toward "the cloud" or whatever makes me very anxious. But it's not some yea or nay decision -- it's happening, and it's up to us to decide what to do with it. Knowing that truly valuable conversations like these are happening, and that they are being reported on, is a comfort amid the endless stream of brainless "books are for Luddites" tablet PC commercials on television.

amarquis,

Are you a Colts fan up there in NE? I've watched every snap, and Painter isn't the problem - other than he isn't Peyton Manning. Considering his inexperience, he's actually been one of the few positives.

The oline is the biggest problem. They were already rebuilding it because it was terrible last year, and all three players they added are now injured. There are several holes on the defense as well, but nothing that Peyton wouldn't have been able to overcome. Just a very disjointed season, but I fully expect them to win some games before all is said and done. Possibly this Sunday. TN isn't exactly in the same class as NO.
Tanier continues to compile a HOF-worthy body of work. A shoo-in for the football analyst Pro Bowl.

Dear Colts, Dolphins, Rams, et al,
Has anyone actually spoken with Andrew Luck to make sure he wants to play NFL football next year? Because it would be pretty embarrassing to go to all the trouble of losing all those games only to find out that Andrew wants to stay in school and become a dentist or something.

Even with the lowest "WAR" of his career, Pujols had better all-around offensive stats than anyone in the NL excluding only Ryan Braun and Matt Kemp (and he did spend nearly a month on the DL, hurrying back because his team needed him).  He's also a great defensive first baseman and a great clubhouse guy.  If St. Louis ownership won't ante up for him their fans should go ballistic.  Give him whatever he wants, even if it's a majority share of the team!

I take no pleasure in saying this, but Ron Washington is not the right manager for a World Series trophy. He is too much a cheerleader & not enough a strategist. The sooner the Rangers realize this, the sooner they can make some changes & get back on track for a Fall Classic win.

The umpiring was ridiculous, but when it is bad it swings both ways. Over a 7 game series it will even out. When Molina walked in the 5th, yes that was a strike. But the pitch right before on a 3-1 count was a ball called a strike, so nothing was gifted.

And, I have to comment on everyone saying the Cardinals are a mediocre team. It is obvious you didn't pay any attention to teams outside The AL East besides their record. Pujols was out for a month, Punto had surgery and 3 total 15 day DL trips, Holliday had an appendectomy, Freeze broke his hand and had a concussion. The team that won last night wasn't playing together consistently until July, and when they did they were dominating (6-3 reg. season record vs the vaulted Phillies).

The cards had the 5th most runs, 5th best batting average, 3rd best on base %, and 6th best slugging % over the regular season. Their achilles heel was pitching which They shored up before the trading deadline. Going back to the end of August, no team played as well as the Cardinals. That is why they won, and why they don't deserve to be called mediocre. They lived up to the potential they had all along which is something you can't say about all the teams who tried to buy a championship.

So this is "adults aged 25 and over" which misses the point. College clearly _was_ worth something 25-35 years ago, and those cohorts are still polluting the measurement with their high earnings.

I want to know if a college degree is valuable (in pecuniary terms) for someone who enroled in the last 5-10 years. Most college-educated people in their 20's that I know have such embarrassingly low-wage jobs that they daren't report them when the university statisticians call.
http://niraj-jha.blogspot.com/

Indian anti-corruption laws were non-existant and a lot of politicians took advantage, siphoning off funds allocated for projects - one of the main reasons for India's problems. At first, Indians did not speak out except behind closed doors because politicians made out that it was disloyal to do so. We were also afraid as consequences of speaking out were too dire for whistle blowers and their loved ones. "India Against Corruption" has united and emboldened Indians with a well thought out action plan and have kept the lines of communication open on many fronts. I have a lot of hope for India. India's time has come. As for America, admire so much about you but please reduce the number of TV programmes where individuals are humiliated by other, to my mind, lesser, human beings.

Mr Mungee’s very subjective opinion emerges from his being conditioned by the 11 years of staying in America. Depending on how deeply the comfort and luxury of the western world had affected his view of life, his experiences in Bangalore were bound to bring out a drastic resurfacing of repressed lamentations. It is like the experimental animals in laboratory facilities who have been conditioned to the life of regulated air, water, and food. If you now let these animals back into the wild – then only the most adaptable will be able to survive…barely. Without an option to return back to the animal facility, the ones who cannot adapt to the life in the wild will perish. Although this is a dramatic analogy, this is what happens when conditioning permeates the psychological make up of a person’s perspective. The persons mind may not be able to adapt to the shift in perspective. They used to say that you can take an Indian out of India, but never India out of an Indian. It may be supposed that this does not strictly apply anymore. Some have been too conditioned to re-adapt to where they came from. It is too wild for them to survive. Like Red says in the Shawshank Redemption – one becomes Institutionalized!
This reminds me of beautiful line from a song by Pink Floyd, ” Did you exchange, a walk-on part in a war, for a lead-role in a cage?”

Unlike in USA and other civilized countries
Selling of meat in India by fringe population(butchery) is
not favoured by even meat eaters), is open and unhealthy. Similarly, packing and preparation and packing of meat food is very unhealthy. It also hearts
Religious feelings of many people to carry leaky food. Except for corrupted controversy vegetarian food does not hurt religious feelings of no body.

The author does not know US yet. Why he left
India is not clear. He probably never knew india in the
First place.

Gr8 piece because every bit is true. And for those who take offense to what you said, let me say it is only because they perpetuate this. if they treated less fortunate better, where would their own status go?? It's always important in India to ensure others have less. We don't respect ourselves and this is evident in the fact how less we respect a fellow human being!! Wonder why Indians were ever called the 'cultured' lot? I don't see any semblance of that anywhere.
Indians are hooligans and we carry this baggage without being aware. In the land of spirituality, we have forgotten how to be a human being, that a human being has more intelligence to give up their animal instincts which is what sets us apart. I believe I like in a jungle where only humans rule like asuras and no one else has any right.

The only thing I know about this girl is one line of her song, "Don't call me Alexandro...", if that was indeed Gaga singing it, that I happened to hear over the music system in a supermarket. I'm not sure why anyone would be willing to pay over $800 to see her perform, unless they have money they don't know what to do with.

Not too long ago some outfit in India invited Sarah Palin. This sounds similar. Indians seem to have a little bit of money these days, so business people bring in new acts from overseas and market them the way P.T.Barnum did. There's a new sucker born every minute!

The policy of Jet Airways was never exposed to the passengers nor displayed at travel agencies or  passengers were intimated of the change of policy. My friend was one of the affected passenger who suffered at the hands of this Jet Airways when he suddenly was denied carrying meat products near the security X-ray machine for his CHECK-IN baggage that was well packed in a hard case. NOT the hand carriage or hand carried cabin baggage. This rule applies for local and international destinations, he was told.  As for me, I will never choose Jet Airways, never like many other Goans. Other airlines don't have this policy including International reputed airlines.

Bravo for Sumedh Mungee's piece, which was honest and not politically correct. If tolerance is what we preach, we could begin by respecting each individual's point of view and not resenting that they don't share our own. Thanks for publishing this.

Hey Editors !
How come you did not mention my name anywhere ? I posted 3 or 4 comments !!!!!
I am deeply offended !! :)) This makes me mad.. It is almost making me write a blog to seek attention ... I am becoming something I am not !!! May be a provocative one... explaining how many years I have been in US ... how many maids I have... How I treat my "servants" and provide them with good bed,AC , TV etc etc.. in short how I preserve the tradition of imperial India and Old Indian culture by employing numerous servants for every menial job that I could have easily done myself. Also I curse in american english slang ( e.g FU ,S**T etc) and never abuse in traditional Indian way like ALL the Indians ( Bhendi.. Maaki.. etc etc )

:)
See ... I had expressed this apprehension earlier too ... NYT has inadvertently created one more Chetan Bhagat ... there you go.

What I still don't understand is this: why is it that one man's leaving (again) is such a big thing to be debated about?

He left. Who cares? Certainly not the 1.25 Billion inhabitants that are still there. This is such a non-issue and gets some fanatical natives riled up against the idiocy of one or two elite, vocal, articulate and lucky (ex)(re)pats.

Times should focus on more serious issues and stay away from such personal non-sense.
This is nothing to do with vegetarianism. No foul smelling food should be allowed inside the plane including curry smell.
maybe it's a natural reaction to how India overwhelms anyone. The difference between western and indian society is plurality-in race,creed,religion

I really don't see the points made by the author. If you think all maids or drivers are liars, then just don't hire them. Just like we are used to "no maids" in US, keep the same in India too. I felt that author's reasoning of why he and family had to leave India was not convincing. It is their person decision, hence no comments but don't just criticize without a strong reasoning. Yes Indian streets are crowded but you knew it beforehand. Like on of the person said, you have to be tougher in India. Also be sensitive and human, they all are not liars!!.

I was one of the many who commented. I am not Indian, so what ? I am a second generation American and think I recognize all that has been said. The writer has become an american. Period. He responds poorly or not at all to what he sees in the "Mother" country because he no longer belongs there. He belongs here. He can be Indian during Diwali [so can I for that matter] then he goes to Mcdonalds [or wherever] . He's ours now and as one us his views are skewed American. No shame in that. Meet you in Jackson Heights at the Indian buffet.
love india & us anyways
